summary: Robert B. Olsen was a Commission staff member involved in taking depositions related to potential CIA involvement in assassination plots. He is mentioned in six documents, primarily in connection with depositions taken in April 1975. Specifically, he is identified as one of the Commission staff members, along with James N. Roethe, who took the deposition of Frank Sturgis and Wilfredo Navarro on April 4, 1975. These depositions focused on potential CIA involvement in assassination plots. Olsen's role appears to be primarily as an investigator or interviewer for the Commission, gathering information from individuals who may have had knowledge of or involvement in relevant activities.
significance: Robert B. Olsen's significance in the JFK assassination context lies in his role as a Commission staff member actively involved in gathering testimony and investigating potential connections between individuals, the CIA, and assassination plots. His work contributed to the official inquiry into the JFK assassination and related matters, particularly concerning the CIA's activities and potential involvement.
